title: Support evolving Golang syntax by switching grammar repo
body: The Go grammar for Vscode is effectively [frozen](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/pull/81015) at this time since the atom syntax it is built from [is no longer maintained](https://github.com/atom/language-go/pull/178#issuecomment-532508206). To my knowledge, the only real change to go syntax highlighting that this affects is for the new print verb `%w` introduced in Go1.13, but there will definitely be more. I would support VScode switching to a community-maintained fork such as [this one](https://github.com/jeff-hykin/better-go-syntax/) or forking and maintaining their own until such time (hopefully) as [tree sitter](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/50140) is a thing and we can resume "borrowing" from Atom once again ;)

title: Python GoToDefinition going to correct line in wrong file
body:
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->
<!-- Also please test using the latest insiders build to make sure your issue has not already been fixed: https://code.visualstudio.com/insiders/ -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issue to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version:
Version: 1.39.1 (user setup)
Commit: 88f15d17dca836346e787762685a40bb5cce75a8
Date: 2019-10-10T23:31:28.683Z
Electron: 4.2.10
Chrome: 69.0.3497.128
Node.js: 10.11.0
V8: 6.9.427.31-electron.0
OS: Windows_NT x64 10.0.18362

Steps to Reproduce:
(I'm using python 3.6.8 64-bit
1. $ git clone https://github.com/takluyver/bash_kernel
2. $ python -m venv ~/.venvs/debug_venv
3. $ source ~/.venvs/debug_venv/bin/activate
4. $ pip install bash_kernel
5. $ python -m bash_kernel.install
6. in VScode, select debug_venv python version
7. open bash_kernel/kernel.py
8. go to line 40, and attempt to go to definition on the `expect_exact` token

Expected behavior:
Should navigate to expect_exact, defined in pexpect's spawnbase.py on line 371

Actual behavior:
Navigates to line 371 in pexpect's pty_spawn.py file

I suspect the issue is that VSCode is recognizing that the `self.child` object is a `pty_spawn.spawn` instance, which is defined in `pty_spawn` and subclasses `SpawnBase` (which is defined in `spawnbase.py`.); when hovering it even shows the correct function definition for `SpawnBase.expect_exact`. It then navigates to the line where the function is defined, in the file where the _class_ is defined, rather than where the actual function is defined.

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: No

title: Feature/pin close others
body:
<!-- Thank you for submitting a Pull Request. Please: 
* Read our Pull Request guidelines:
  https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/wiki/How-to-Contribute#pull-requests.
* Associate an issue with the Pull Request.
* Ensure that the code is up-to-date with the `master` branch.
* Include a description of the proposed changes and how to test them. 
-->

Currently when someone selects 'Close Others' on an unpinned editor, the editor remains unpinned.

That behavior seemed inconsistent to me since moving an editor around in a group or to a new group pins it. I think it makes sense that if someone is saying to close all editors apart from one, that the one editor should be pinned.

I also made it so an editor is pinned if someone selects 'Close to the right', but I'm less sure of that behavior. If this behavior remains, does it make sense to pin any unpinned editors to the left?

I don't have a problem adding tests, but I didn't see where the relevant tests were.

Here's the new behavior
![close others vscode](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3896310/66792611-234e2980-eebf-11e9-97d4-6c8b2d7414c7.gif)

title: can not get env data when debug a python file with root privilege
body:
- VSCode Version: 88f15d17dca836346e787762685a40bb5cce75a8
- OS Version:macOS Catalina

Steps to Reproduce:

1. create a python file 
```
import os

print(os.getenv('ENV_DATA'))

```
2.add launch.json debug file
```
{
            "name": "python dev",
            "type": "python",
            "request": "launch",
            "console": "integratedTerminal",
            "args": [
                "${file}"
            ],
            "envFile": "${workspaceFolder}/.vscode/dev.env",
            "sudo": true
}
```
3. create dev.env file
# dev.env - development configuration
ENV_DATA=hello

4. debug the python file , the print result is "None", expect result should be "hello"

title: Please produce a signed VS Code package so it can be installed Windows 10 S Mode
body: Issue Type: Feature Request VS Code cannot be installed in S mode because it is not signed. Some basic development activities like working on web pages would be nice to do in S mode, or even just the ability to have VS Code as a better editor than Notepad from first-party for editing text. Having the binary signed by Microsoft in such a way that makes Windows 10 S mode happy would probably be a good thing in any case. title: Multi-Cursor select broken by overriding keymappings for javascript
body:
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->
<!-- Also please test using the latest insiders build to make sure your issue has not already been fixed: https://code.visualstudio.com/insiders/ -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issue to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.39.1
- OS Version: Mojave 10.14.6

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Go to `Selection` > `Switch to Alt+Click for Multi-Cursor`
2. In any Javascript or JSX file, hold Alt (same key as `option` on macbook pro) and click and drag down onto a word that is recognized as defineable.
3. One of two bugs will happen: 1) The editor will pop the definition window breaking the multi-line selection or 2) VScode moves the cursor to the beginning of the word last touched by the multi-line selection

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
With no extensions installed this still occurs.

title: Edge case with cursorUndo
body:
After making edits that don't move the cursor (with commands such as `deleteRight`, `deleteWordRight`, `copyLinesUp`, `deleteLines`) the first cursor move following it is ignored by `cursorUndo`.

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Type <kbd>hello</kbd>
2. Press <kbd>Left</kbd>
3. Press <kbd>Delete</kbd>, the `o` should be deleted
4. Press <kbd>Left</kbd>
5. Press <kbd>Ctrl</kbd>+<kbd>U</kbd> - nothing happens

Expected behavior: The cursor should move back to the end.

The implementation of the `cursorUndo` command assumes that an edit will be immediately followed by a cursor move. This is usually true but not always, as you can make modifications without moving the cursor. And those will cause the next cursor move to not be registered in the cursor undo stack.

- VSCode Version: 1.39.1
- OS Version: Windows 10
- Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes

title: Adding three finger swipe with various options.
body:
Following options have been added: 
* `'actions'` -> `Swipes will navigate recent action history.`
* `'tabs'` -> `Swipes will navigate currently opened tabs.` 
* `'recent-tabs'` -> `Swipes will navigate recent tab history.`
* `'grouped-tabs'` -> `Swipes will navigate currently opened tabs in selected group.`

Fix: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/4803 (again) 
Based on changes from: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/commit/e368b34ac39fc1ca51e553d91a08ae2cf13048d2 from @bpasero  & and my own PR https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/pull/23663 

Also fixes the confusion on what a swipe is supposed to do.
It seems most people just want **or** expect it to move between tabs, while I like it to function in similar fashion as Xcode. 
These added options allows user to toggle their preferred setting. But it only works with a *three* **(3)** finger Swipe, as that's what the exposed Electron API uses. 

Discussions: 
https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/40526
https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/25447
https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/25325
https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/25449

title: Debugging with 'autoAttachChildProcesses' not working
body:
Issue Type: Bug I wrote this small script to use `cluster` to launch some subprocesses: **index.js** ```js const cluster = require('cluster'); if (cluster.isMaster) { console.log(`Master ${process.pid} is running`); // Fork 4 workers. for (let i = 0; i < 4; i++) { const WORKER_NUM = i; cluster.fork({ WORKER_NUM }); } cluster.on('exit', (worker, code, signal) => { console.log(`worker ${worker.process.pid} died`); }); } else { console.log(`Worker ${process.pid} started ${process.env.WORKER_NUM}`); // Add a breakpoint on only the 3rd worker if (process.env.WORKER_NUM === '3') { console.log("I am worker 3!"); } } ``` This is my `launch.json` file: ```json { "version": "0.2.0", "configurations": [ { "type": "node", "request": "launch", "name": "Cluster", "program": "${workspaceFolder}/index.js", "autoAttachChildProcesses": true } ] } ``` When I hit the "play" button on that config it looks like the subprocesses never run: ``` $ cd /tmp/tmp.Y3yEbU3KdQ ; /usr/local/google/home/samstern/.nvm/versions/node/v10.16.0/bin/node --inspect-brk=40242 index.js Debugger listening on ws://127.0.0.1:40242/b3cb7ac5-3710-42f9-b1be-9d9ca4fb4560 For help, see: https://nodejs.org/en/docs/inspector Debugger attached. Master 236270 is running Debugger listening on ws://127.0.0.1:40243/7bf74bcc-fefc-4198-9401-de7800347383 For help, see: https://nodejs.org/en/docs/inspector Debugger listening on ws://127.0.0.1:40244/2781e1a6-92b5-4c08-87c7-4e3a02fbbf11 For help, see: https://nodejs.org/en/docs/inspector Debugger listening on ws://127.0.0.1:40245/dea14bce-05f5-4251-9c31-3982199abc11 For help, see: https://nodejs.org/en/docs/inspector Debugger listening on ws://127.0.0.1:40246/06effd32-5b73-434a-b83f-5787446de974 For help, see: https://nodejs.org/en/docs/inspector ``` If I just run the script, they do run; ``` $ node index.js Master 236586 is running Worker 236595 started 1 Worker 236594 started 0 Worker 236596 started 2 Worker 236598 started 3 I am worker 3! ``` So it looks like the subprocesses are getting `--inspect-brk` but the debugger is never attaching (and giving a continue signal) so they can't actually get to my code. VS Code version: Code 1.39.1 (88f15d17dca836346e787762685a40bb5cce75a8, 2019-10-10T23:30:33.955Z) OS version: Linux x64 4.19.37-5+deb10u2rodete2-amd64

1. Open cmd or powershell on integrated terminal on VSCode
2. run `node test.js` (after `npm i`)

4. run the same `node test.js` on native cmd or powershell => everything is OK

Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes

* all our built in extensions

title: Support for interactive git hooks?
body:
I wrote a global `git` hook for spell checking commit messages. It displays to the user a list of possible spelling mistakes (if any) and prompts to either abort the commit and modify the message or proceed anyway.

Everything works as expected on the command line. But using VS Code's built-in source control UI, I get the error `/dev/tty: Device not configured`.

Any way for VS Code to support interactive `git` hooks?

**Global `commit-msg` hook**
```sh
#!/bin/sh

if ! command -v aspell &>/dev/null; then
  printf "%s\n" "[commit-msg hook] Warning: 'aspell' not installed. Unable to spell check commit message."
else
  wordList=( $(grep -v "^  " "$1" | aspell list) )
fi

if (( "${#wordList[@]}" > 0 )); then
  printf "%s\n" "[commit-msg hook] Possible spelling errors found in commit message:" "${wordList[@]}"
fi

exec < /dev/tty

while true; do
  read -p "[commit-msg hook] Proceed anyway? (y/n) " yn
  if [ "$yn" = "" ]; then
    yn='y'
  fi
  case $yn in
      [Yy] ) break;;
      [Nn] ) exit 1;;
      * ) echo "Please answer y for yes or n for no.";;
  esac
done
```

title: Command and Keybinding for adding multi cursor from search result
body:
<!-- Thank you for submitting a Pull Request. Please: 
* Read our Pull Request guidelines:
  https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/wiki/How-to-Contribute#pull-requests.
* Associate an issue with the Pull Request.
* Ensure that the code is up-to-date with the `master` branch.
* Include a description of the proposed changes and how to test them. 
-->

This PR fixes #81407

title: Startup ~100ms slower with Electron 6
body: The perf bot shows that builds running Electron 6 are starting roughly 100ms slower (1835ms vs 1723ms). We should understand why and we should try to get that time back. Seems to only happen with windows.

title: Improve handling of invalid built-in extension manifest files
body:
https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/82359 Shows how fragile the extensions system is wrt built-in extension loading errors. We should improve the following:

- A single thrown exception in [`ExtensionManifestParser`](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/blob/2e5e00128caf847cc6630e69af34810d4d042668/src/vs/workbench/services/extensions/node/extensionPoints.ts#L50) should not disable all built-in extensions
- That exception message should contain information about [which extension failed to load](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/82181#issue-504906007).
- Failure to load a built-in extension currently shows no error message whatsoever.

I could confirm none of these points are respected by forcing an error when parsing the manifest file by simply wiping out the contents of a built-in extension's `package.json`.

cc @aeschli

title: Extension Host Terminated unexpectedly
body:
Issue Type: Bug After upgrade from 1.37.1 to 1.38 or 1.39 of VS-Code the "extension host terminates unexpectedly". This happens also on a clean install without any modifications, extensions... title: Indent NPM Scripts
body:
We have a monorepo frontend with multiple applications, which in turn results in a lot of scripts in package.json.

We love the "npm scripts" panel, but it would be even better if we in some way could arrange the scripts as one application typically has run, build, test, testonce, analyze and maybe even more sub-features.

It seems to be a pattern to name scripts with a colon separator "myapp:run", "myapp:test" and so on.

If the panel could make a tree-like structure of the scripts, based on splitting the names on ":", it would be more readable and easier to find the script you need.

Coloring and/or icons for keywords(like run, test, build) could also provide useful

The result could then be something like:
```
myapp1
        run
        test
        build
myapp2
        run
        test
        build
```
